reviewText:
Early Access Review

Feature        Y/N/Rating                SLI        No                Aspect Ratios        16:9, Others Unknown                Triple Monitor        Unknown                Framerate Cap        120-144+                FOV        Yes, 2 Sliders                Key Rebinding        Full                Controller Support/Rebinding        No                Options        Extensive                Performance        Great
PC Port Quality
The options are extremely extensive. You can map all of the controls including toggle/hold zooming. You have two separate FOV sliders for general and while zooming (up to 160 degrees) and separate mouse sensitivities for each and separate x/y axis adjustment, and y invert. You can toggle almost all of the visual effects like bloom/vignette, as well as outlines for players and objects. You can control the the color/style of everything from the crosshair, to your in-game name, the enemy and team colors, two level saturation sliders, etc. It has auto contract color picking, and the only thing better I'd like would be per-level enemy color selection. I use a red-pink, and I have to manually switch them to a green or cyan for the red/black level. You can turn off hit decals, force the default beam and death animation for enemies, hide/move the weapon model. It's a ridiculous amount of customization, and it runs great too. It doesn't have a dedicated fullscreen mode, and while that sucks, it's an issue that all Unity devs have to deal with. It starts up, loads, and closes very quickly, and the menus work very well, making mid-match changes very doable.

Gameplay
It's by far the fastest game I've ever played, and it feels extremely good. I found the zoom function unusable at first because of the static sensitivity, but then I found the sensitivity scaling slider, and it works great. The players are pretty small objects in the environment, so extremely long ranges happen frequently, but the movement is extremely fast and close range engagements happen often so you need a higher sensitivity to do well. So having the zoom and essentially two separate sensitivities, really helps. The sliders are numerical, so you should be able to keep the mouse to screen distance ratio the same at both FOV values, with a little math. I do wish you could disable the death animations of your own player, as certain ones can shoot the camera across the map and I don't find it very appealing.

The game is rather limited in terms of modes and maps, though a map editor was just announced and one would assume that comes with workshop support. That's good for the future, but at the moment it feels limited. The gameplay is so satisfying if you have a knack for it, but I did have a problem. I played for 2 days without issue, nothing feeling unfair at all, but all of a sudden on the third day, it because quite inconsistent. The player count was at 1600+, vs the ~700 of the two days prior. It could be my connection, and though my ping was only ~30, the game got drastically less fun. The boost (rocket jump) function is essential for quick acceleration which makes you a hard target, but if it outright fails to activate 15% of the time, you die because you stay in place when you should have shot off in another direction. It was much harder to see this, but there were also instances of shots missing randomly at all sorts of ranges. The game was updated without patch notes before I played the 3rd day. I had zero issues in this respect for about 4 hours of play across the two days prior. It could be my connection, it could be the update, it could be the servers, but whatever it is made me not want to play when I loved it the days before. It's so dependent on that speed and responsiveness, that if anything takes it away, the fun is gone.

There are two things to unlock in the game. One I'm fine with, while the other is problematic. The beam shape and death animations are unlocked via by getting achievements tied to killstreaks, the highest being 3 Monsterkills, which I believe is 6 in a row (not just without dying, but in very quick succession as well). Some of the others are tied to winning x number of the various match types. I mean I'd strive for zero unlocks at all, but these are harmless. Next is customization items for your character, that are given via a random drop system. Thankfully there are no microtransactions tied to it, but I still really do not see the point of it. It limits player choice and expression right out of the gate, and it just gets stupid people to blow $80 on some half-♥♥♥♥♥ textureless 3D model on the steam marketplace. The game is so old-school and consumer oriented in every other aspect, that this one system contrasts immensely in what is a paid title. Better this than microtransactions, but it's needless regardless.

Presentation
I think the rats are unappealing, and I'd like to toggle off the death animations and gore effects, but the levels and overall visuals are nice. The menus are very basic but work without issue. The levels almost all look straight out of Mirror's Edge and I really like them. I'd love to view them in full color, but the advantages of having the level saturation <~30% are too much to give up when really trying to do well. I will say though that if per-level enemy color and saturation settings were an option, that would be amazing. If you want the most advantage the way it is now, the best option is to go with low saturation, unless you want to manually adjust it before every round.

TLDR - Summary
At it's best, I love this game. It feels amazing and nailing awesome shots or streaking is hugely satisfying. That said I would be wary for multiple reasons. If connection problems occur, the fun goes out the window because of the insane skill requirement. I also play on a 120Hz display with ultra-low motion blur enabled, and I'm not sure how well it would really fare without that, again because of the insane speed of everything. Finally, player count could be a real issue at some point. For months before the Free Weekend that's occurring as I write this, the game had less than 20 players. And because of the price it's offered at, I'm not sure how many players will actually buy the game and continue playing after the promotion. It has no single-player content, so unless you have a friend to 1v1 against, you're boned if no one else is online. The game has a 1v1 mode vs a random player, but a tiny pool of players means the ranking system can't really do it's job well and you'll be matched with the same insane player endlessly. I'd more than recommend it on a very cheap sale or bundle because that's sure to bring in some players for a while and the low price means even if you can only play for that week, it's not as much of a let-down as it could be at a more substantial price point. But that's up to the buyer, as some expect an hour of fun for their dollar, while others might want five to ten which is very achievable in the current market. It could use some small tweaks, but most of all I just think it needs a consistent playerbase. It's still early access, so an official release plus an even more substantial sale could very well make that happen. Because of the intensity and limited maps/modes for now it's not really something suited to binge-play, but it's something I could easily see hopping on every day or two for 30 mins to an hour if that was an option.

What can I say about Ratz Instagib? Well it is a railgun, instagib multiplayer shooter which incorporates the rocket-jumping mechanic familiar to Quake and Team Fortress 2.
The game is surprisingly simplistic; move around and shoot, however a combination of rocket-jumping and the 1-hit-kill railgun create an intense, competitive environment where timing and precision is your key to success.

Not only does Ratz bring back great memories of Quake II railgun battles and Unreal Tournament's instagib mode, it has its own merits—primarily the level of customization which creates a very level playing field and a very personal experience—you are free to individualise almost all aspects of the game from the colour of your railgun beam to the colour of your name, team mates and enemies.

The newly introduced item drop system is purely based around cosmetics which maintains the balance and integrity of the game.

Game-modes include Team/One man army Deathmatch, Freeze Tag, CTF mode and most likely more to be introduced in future updates.

Updates seem to be introduced on a relatively frequent basis but at this point, the game looks very much like a finished product:
Clean and colourful UI,
Ecletic map design,
A plethora of customisation options,
Fluid player movement and extremely stable latency/servers.
Hatz   :B1:These features successfully disguise the fact that it is an early access game and are the reasons why I highly recommend Ratz Instagib!!

Side note: This game truly is a hidden gem and desperately needs more love and publicity from the community and devs, it would be a shame for such a beautiful game to be neglected and go to waste.

I use to play this a long time ago when it was a browser game on kongregate.com. The first time I played it, I knew it had potential.

The game is exactly what it says - you're a bunch of rats hopping around playing instagib. There's free-for-all, Team deathmatch, freeze tag, capture the flag, duel and even a little survival mode to mess around on, all using only railguns. The movement feels very smooth. There's railjumping, and bunny hopping is a lot of fun (and the key to success).

Another thing I feel compelled to mention is the customization in this game. You can almost edit everything from simple graphics options like toggling Bloom and cell-shading on/off, to wall and/or prop saturation, FOV, HUD, enemy colors, your rail color, death animation/fx, and your rat itself with cosmetics. The music plays like a little radio in the corner and you can hit pause to change it at any time you want. The music kind of has that late 90's feel, reminds me of the Dreamcast days. It's awesome.

The game has a lot of maps for an Early Access game and is getting great support from it's lone developer who is active on the forums listening to suggestions and squashing new bugs rather fast, which is always great. I'm impressed with how far this game has gone and I can definitely suggest this game, especially to those who loved playing instagib mods back in the day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ratz Instagib, a game I played really early on, and now that it's on Steam with noticeable improvements, prettier, more maps, more customization, unlockable cosmetics, more game modes, private matches, and more fun.

The game is for people who hunger for the 'Instagib' game mode, like me, because its hard to get really good ones nowadays, aside from the old ones that has it, but this game has a focus one that one game mode only, which is Instagib, meaning insta-kill, one shot one kill, and this one is a great one, and as far as I know, it's the best one.

All the game modes are great, duel mode, death match, team death match, capture the flag, freeze tag, and survival. I haven't tried freeze tag yet, but everything else is nice, fun, and competitive, the most competitive an FPS can be actually, and it's not just doing matches and winning, there's a skill progression in which the game monitors your skill and ranks you accordingly. There's also unlockables that you can set a goal for to unlock, these unlockables are only cosmetic and will not change the games simple fair and competitive nature.

The one thing I have an issue with is the same issue I have with any multiplayer game only, and that is it doesn't have bots to sustain the game if there are no players to play it at any given time, so keep that in mind, but it has a game mode in which you can play the game and shoot at things, and that is the survival game mode, it's a solo or coop game made where you (your self or with your friends) go up against a horde of unique (land and flying) enemies where you have to dodge their slow orb-like projectiles, and shoot their core at the center of their bodies, so it's not normal bots of the same type as you with the same weapons, but it's good, requires more precision, and good to play solo or with your friends as coop. It's better than nothing one would say.

For the asking price, for the fan that I am for Instagib, and for the content that it has and future content that it will have, it's worth it, even more so if they add normal insta-gibbing bots to play with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr -> If you were born during the Unreal, Quake, and Scouts-Knives era, then pick up this game already. It's sniper paintball with boosting. And everyone's on speed. 11/10.

The developer was kind enough to give out a bunch of keys when this game launched on steam, and a good friend got me a key even though I had missed the giveaway by 15 minutes. I was very excited to feel all the nostalgia of my instagibbing days. The experience was satisfying and great.

If you enjoy instagib (one hit kill) gameplay, boosting (shooting the ground to shoot yourself upwards), twitch shooting, and an intense, fast-paced FPS experience, then you will enjoy this game.

As a disclaimer, I always try to avoid mentioning the price of a game if I feel that its mechanics make up for any monetary value, however, for the current price ($9.99), the game is more than a finished product for an early-access game. Believe me, you will get your money's worth for this price if you are looking for a no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t instagib experience.

The aesthetics are very good - the levels are nice and bright and colorful. You can customize everything from the color/type of your laser beam, to the type of explosions when you kill an opponent, to the color of your character model (and your opponents'). Personally, I prefer to have the environment in greyscale and the enemy in a bright, pop-out color (red). You can even change the color of your name in-game. When you shoot, it will leave a paintball-style mark in the color of your laser - by the end of the match, the area will look like a paintball battlefield. The music and sounds are very good, especially if you like electronic music.

The controls are typical of a traditional FPS, however, you will need to get used to the instagib style if you are a newcomer - boosting (shooting the ground to propel yourself) and constantly moving is a necessity to survival. Being able to shoot from a far is also essential (you can play around with the FOV, however, I feel that the max setting is a bit disorienting). Be warned, the instagib community for most games is relentless and unforgiving, so don't be surprised or disheartened if you have a hard time getting kills. From the servers I've played, the community seems very friendly. There is no tutorial, and the learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with FPS games - in particular, with the instagib game mode.

Gameplay is extremely fast-paced - you must constantly remain on the move. There are a variety of game modes, like deathmatch and team deathmatch. The online community is fairly small, but still decent - you might not always have a full server. Everyone dies with one hit, and you can shoot across the entire map. Staying mobile, timing your boost jumps, and maintaining battlefield awareness (this is where the high DPI players will get to flex their skills) is critical to doing well in this game.

Overall, the instagib game mode is represented very, very well in Ratz, and anyone interested in that style of FPS should definitely check this out.

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: as of the date of this review, the game is still in early access so things might have changed in the meantime

Ratz Instagib is a no-b*llsh*t, super fast-paced shooter where anyone can jump in and learn how to play in seconds. At the same time, Ratz Instagib is almost completely skill-based and your aiming and movement skills (which take months to master, especially the aim) directly determine the outcome of the game.
The game mechanics are as simple as it can get: you only have one weapon, the railgun, which is a one hit kill and you can boost in any direction (kind of like a rocket jump) by right clicking. The enemy hitboxes are extremely small and movement is extremely fast, which means that you have to be extremely good at aiming to hit your enemies.

Pros:
+ Very fast paced gameplay
+ Balanced, competitive gameplay
+ Partially skill-based movement (you need to get good at keeping your momentum to maintain your speed)
+ Responsive and smooth controls
+ Lots of customizations in the options menu (enemy colors, beam color, nickname color, X and Y mouse velocity, and a ton of other graphical options).
+ Performance is pretty good even though the game is made in Unity. I'm getting ~250fps on a i7-4790k and Sapphire r9 270x running at 1920x1080@120hz.
+ Multiple gamemodes

Cons:
- Could've used a proprietary engine with better optimization than Unity
- Could've included non-instagib gamemodes with the standard arena fps weapons and pickups
- No ability to host a dedicated server
- No map editor / custom maps

I highly recommend this as it's a lot of fun and also a great aim warm-up for games like Quake.

Oh wow! I just got done playing my first game...

I started up a random team deathmatch game and as it began it was 1v1 which was surprisingly fun. Maybe because I was winning, but a couple minutes after that was 2v2 and it became a little more competetive and the pace started to pick up. Then before I knew it the room was a madhouse of colors and sounds as it became a 4 vs 4.

People (Rats) flying all over the place, tracer rounds streaking across random distant areas then flying across your face, trying to pick out a target in crowd of enemies and allies only to be unexpectedly blown up by someone you didn't know was targetting you the whole time.

I thought this game was going to be fun but I was plesantly surprised as to how much fun. The beauty is in its simplicity. With 1 shot kills and equipment being equal for all players the battlefield stays fair enough to maintain the fun. This game proves that you don't need much to have a blast in an online shooter, which is by far my favorite genere of games. That being said, I expect a certain amount of fun in my FPS and this game delivers.

The rooms are common place areas however you're the size of a rat so they're huge and with the boost feature (a big jump) you can fly nearly halfway across the map as well as get to all areas of the map. Boost up to the book shelf to shoot the guy on the living room table. Soar over the sofa to snipe the guy under the TV. Never a dull moment.

Multiple game types; Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Freeze Tag (thats a new one), and several others.
Statistics to keep track of you're K/D ratio as well as double, triple, quadruple kill and 2 more above that.
Some unlockables like tracer effects and frag type/color.
Choose the color of multiple items including your gametag.
And there's a decient amount of other ways to customize your gaming experience.

Bottom line, it's fun and a great way to kill some time... and rats.

Awesome game for any fan of instagib, a mode of play in which a single shot gibs your opponent, popularized by Quake and Unreal Tournament and made into it's own game along with various game modes such as deathmatch, team deathmatch, capture the flag and so on. The mechanics are basic but rock solid, can't be faulted in any way, the hitbox is on point meaning no bs, the speed is crazy and the secondary fire on your railgun thrusts you high into the air allowing for fun maneuvering, the maps are well designed, allowing for great flow, it's aesthetically pleasing consisting of a diverse and warm colour palette and gives you a lot of options to customize your game such as changing the field of view, crosshair colour/size/type, character model colours etc. It must also be added that this game has solid netcode, I can play on UK servers from South Africa with hardly feeling any lag.

The asking price is 8.99$ which is pretty fair in my opinion, especially if you're a massive fan of instagib. This game is currently in Early Access so will be interesting to see the additions they add to this already awesomely fun game.

Early Access Review

Alright, listen up. You will either like this game or hate this game. If you enjoy trying to kill people at high speeds while jumping around a map while your enemies do the same YOU WILL LOVE THIS GAME! Otherwise, you will probably hate it.

Lets talk about the movement. It's fast and it's all over the place, tapping spacebar as you hit the ground will let you bunny hop and if you do that enough times in a row you will be going pretty fast. Add to that a rocket jump like boost by right clicking while looking at a wall or the ground and you will be a 2fast2quick machine. Think of the scout from tf2 and then just give him the rocket jumper. It's that amazing.

Secondly lets talk about the gunplay. You get one gun, a lazer, you can customize it to be whatever color you want and then you just shoot people, it's a one shot kill. This game will beat you up with it too. There are people who are really good at aiming that thing. But for the 100s of times you will die, that one kill you get will give you the best damn feeling ever.

Lastly lets talk about maps, there aren't a lot right now, but they are all very unique, my favorite currently being the office map and least favorite being the pool map. They all have ways to gain speed and things that will get in your way and stop you. With that being said though, I would like to see some kind of map creator or something in the future, could be fun.

Final thoughts: Just get the damn game. If you loved quake and other arena shooters like it, jthis brings in the best parts and just makes it its own game. Seriously though, once you get a taste of the speed and adrenaline of getting that first kill, it will be hard to switch back to games like Call of duty or Counter strike.

EARLY ACCESS! JUST SUGGESTIONS, NOT A FULL REVIEW!

Hey, first off love the game! Lots of good things, love the beam and frag types and the aesthetic is awesome, but I've noticed a few things that could be improved upon.

1. In the arena mode 8 players is just too much, I've asked around in 8 player matches and the concensus seems to be 6 players is best. I know it's subjective, but the difference in games between 6 and 8 people is REALLY noticable, spawns become pretty B.S., it's way less feasable to just have a short shootout with 1 (or 2) people, etc.

2. The game needs to let you join an empty server instead of sending you on an empty loop, if you let people sit in that room and jump around (like when you host a server by yourself) and let people join into that matches would happen MUCH quicker, people tend to just leave the infinite qeue after awhile. If we can just spawn onto the map (and maybe eventually get bots in) that would be great. (I realize this was probably done to prevent everyone from getting put into an empty match when there's partially full ones available, but since the games pop is currently so low it should join you into a match after it's gone through the full server list.)

3. The rank system needs to account for people who joined the match late, if you join in the last half of the match you still get rank points based on your position as if you'd been there the whole time.

3. The red map with the big pool just doesn't seem to play that well in my experience, the map doesn't really feel cohesive, the area in the middle is ok (if a little crowded and chaotic) but the outer area has a lot of wasted space that means you have people sniping from a far distance, and if they try to get closer they're kindof penalized cus they have to go pretty straight to get back to the middle, giving the people in the middle a slight advantage.

Technically I haven't noticed much wrong, in a few hours of play there was one instance where the server stuttered for a second or so, but nothing since or previously, probably just a one off thing. It would be nice though if clicking onto another monitor accidentally didn't automatically minimize the game. Capturing the mouse would be another way to fix this.

Thanks again for the great game! Loving it so far.

First Impression Review
Great insta-kill fun. Ratz Instagib is a potent little game about you controlling rats and fragging other rats with your insta-kill railgun. Awesome drum and bass soundtrack curated by Jazzsticks, even though I'm a metal aficionado and don't normally prefer the genre - it gives both a frantic and relaxing feeling at the same time.

Matches are incredibly fun and fast-paced. A dedicated rocket jump feature adds another dimension to it - jump and make crazy moves dodging your opponent's shots while shooting them back. One of the most recent implementations are tradeable and marketable cosmetic equips that can be used to customise your rat.

While the basic game mechanics are great, Ratz however needs more players and more servers though. At times it can be hard to find a match, and when one is found, I've lost quite a few kills due to high ping, living on the wrong side of the world. (Incidentally, I'm not using that as an excuse for my poor play - I do suck. This ping issue just makes it worse for me.) The Japan server is practically barren - Australia would probably be a good choice for adding more servers for Asian people.

Still, this is an infinitely better game than another Rats game on Steam which I shall not name here.

The music in this game is unique, and I'd say that it's sort of catchy. The gameplay is very smooth, and I love the feel of the high movement speed given to all players. It goes very well with the maps which are just rooms that the player sees in a larger perspective because they're playing as a rat. I feel that it's a brilliant idea, actually. Something that I get annoyed with in most first-person-shooters is registry. The railguns in this game (which are the only guns) always kill with one shot, and I feel like I can fairly except that when I did not hit an enemy I missed and the registry isn't absolute ♥♥♥♥ (*cough cough* CS:GO). The game is easy to run with graphics that aren't ugly but aren't outstanding. The game looks very clean, but it just doesn't have enough detail. The game also lacks content, and by content I mean gamemodes, maps, weapons, customization, etc. Another thing that it lacks is player count. There unfortunately aren't many people that play Ratz Instagib at the moment, and many of the few that do are insanely skilled. Sometimes I will hop on and see that there are literally zero players currently playing on the NA servers, and then when there are those players are most of the time gods. If the developers added more content and if more people played this game, it would be a masterpiece in my eyes. Currently it's not worth the money though. Anyway, I still enjoy it.

I give this game a rating of 7/10.

I'm a huge fan of instagib (from Quake 2/3/Live, UT etc) and really want games like this to succeed!

- Colour scheme/art style/visuals:  I think it could really do with some work in this area.  Sometimes it's hard to pick out players amongst the various colourful effects, decals etc.  I don't think it's an impossible problem to solve, just some minor changes to the colour palette used for players versus what's used for effects could help, or possibly the use of a different outline shader (edit: I'll admit I haven't played around with the graphics options available here which might solve this, but if that's the case then perhaps the defaults could be improved).  In regards to the overall visuals, I think it could do with some polish... while I appreciate the oldschool style of the frontend/HUD some of it clashes quite badly and makes my head hurt!  The characters themselves also look quite rigid at the moment, again just polish needed there with the animations.

- Hit registration:  There appears to be a bug here, sometimes you'll hit someone, get the ding noise and they'll flash white but they won't die.  It isn't because their hit registered first, because you don't die either... it's simply some weird inconsistency between the client and the server it seems.  Upon mentioning it on the server chat other people all said they experienced the same thing in the same game.  I'm sure this will get fixed, but for the time being it's a little annoying when it happens as you feel robbed of a kill (though it's possible you simply didn't hit them on the server).

- Movement mechanics:  I'm in two minds about this one, to be honest I find it a little too floaty for my liking... though the boost mechanic (rocket-jumping with your gun essentially) is interesting and adds some depth to the movement (I'm terrible at using it though).

- Matchmaking/Servers:  Currently there isn't proper matchmaking, undoubtedly due to the small playerbase right now (as the game isn't Free to Play this isn't surprising).  That said, I've not had a problem finding a regular deathmatch game yet.  An issue this does introduce though is that you can get stomped by the players that have played the game for a while, however they all appear to be very friendly and happy to sit out of matches so others can have fun.  Don't let this put you off buying or playing this game, as there are plenty of noobs just like you and I.

Overall it's a nice idea, a game dedicated to instagib is definitely something I'm happy to back!  Whether it's worth the price of admission depends on how much of an instagib enthusiast you are and whether you're happy to support a developer making a game in a genre you love.  I look forward to seeing how this game evolves and I'm happy to update this review as it does.

Ratz Instagib takes a different direction in fps game development by creating an original concept & working off it, rather than the add more explosions, xp ranks/rewards & gun skins mentality. The result is a simple yet highly effective end product that's fun because of the core gameplay.

The gameplay is a variation of instagib deathmatch where your rail gun has a secondary rocket jump fire mode, & you have full air control ala Painkiller/CPMA. Despite being in early access, the game already has enough content to be considered as a full game. There are 6 modes: DM, TDM, CTF, Freezetag, Duel & a co-op wave based survival mode which isn't very good unfortunately, as well as over 10 maps.

For $5, I highly recommend this game, 7/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRatz Instagib is a very fast-paced, FPS Arena game, where the object is to kill the opposing team as quickly as possible. Visually you play from the perspective of a rat or mouse, so the levels look like rooms of buildings or houses, but everything is jumbo sized. I think the appeal of this game is it's simplicity: One shot, One kill. Currently there are 13 different Maps, but from what I've read they do have a map editor so people may actually be able to create their own maps. The game does a good job of balancing the PVP, if someone leaves or joins, each round the game auto-rebalances, which makes it better than some high end FPS games, which allow unbalanced teams. I thought it was fun, though I only played it for a short time, just enough to get a feel for it. If you like FPS Arena styled PVP games and want something fast-paced, Ratz Instagib has that in abundance.

Hello!
If you came here for a review, you're out of luck... But if you're looking for a chicken and mushroom puff pie recipe YOU CAME TO THE RIGHT PLACE :D

Let's get started!
Ingredients:
-1 tbsp vegetable oil
-8 skinless boneless chicken thighs
-8 rashers smoked streaky bacon, cut into large pieces
-1 onion, halved and sliced
-250g pack baby button mushrooms
handful thyme sprigs
-2 tbsp plain flour
-400ml chicken stock
-200ml milk
-500g pack fresh puff pastry, or frozen and defrosted
-1 egg, beaten

Method:
1. Heat the oil in a large, non-stick frying pan. Season the chicken to taste and fry for 5-8 mins until golden brown, turning occasionally. You may need to do this in two batches, depending on the size of your pan. Lift the chicken onto a plate and tip the bacon into the pan. Fry for 5 mins until crisp. Add the onion, mushrooms and thyme, then fry on a high heat for another 3 mins until the onions start to colour.
2. Tip the flour into the pan and cook, stirring, for 1 min. With the pan off the heat, gradually stir or whisk in the stock, followed by the milk, then add the chicken back to the pan. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 30 mins. Spoon the filling into a large pie or baking dish (approx 20 x 30cm) with a lip and leave to cool.
3. Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. On a floured surface, roll the pastry to the thickness of two £1 coins. Cut a long strip as wide as the rim of the pie dish and, using a little of the egg, fix to the edge of the pie dish. Brush with egg, then lift the rest of the pastry over the pie, using the rolling pin to help. Gently press the edges with your fingers and trim with a sharp knife. Brush lightly with egg to glaze, then bake for 30 mins or until the pastry is risen and dark golden brown.

Or the number of options and strategies that can overwhelm the player when he's not into that kind of game especially when the last in mind was released fifteen years old: Quake 3 Arena. Is your crosshair too bright ? Too small or too big ?

You can customize your kills and your Ratz with some achievements in-game or random item drops during matches which add a true bonus to characters options
date:
overall fun and life span.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easy to pick up, hard to master, and overall really fun to play.

This whole review in two sentences: If you don't mind being fragged a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you will really enjoy this game.  Listen to the in game music, your own music or a podcast, sit back, and instagib.

The movement system stays relatively simple while being pretty damn fun.  WASD to move, space to jump, and right click to boost yourself off a wall or the ground.  Repetitively jumping in a direction will gain speed faster than walking on the ground would.  Boosting off objects can be done consecutively to the point where you can climb walls or even quickly zip between walls to the point where you never touch the ground.

The shooting is extremely simple, but it brings in a major skill curve.  If you can click on someone, one shot from your instagib lazer will kill them.  The big contingency being if you click them.  The skill curve of this game quickly shifts from movement to aim.  Aim is what seperates the noobs and pros.  People with fps experience are at an extreme advantage.  I've been owned by people playing their first game Ratz Instagib because they are Global Elite in CS:GO or have a few thousand hours of competitive TF2 under their belt.

You WILL OWN the people worse than you, and you WILL GET OWNED by the people better than you.  If you can't realize that, this game isn't for you.  If you make the choice to drop the ego and enjoy the game, you WILL see yourself improving.  If you can't drop the ego, you won't have a very fun time with this game.  Because of these truths, this game has one of the chillest communities.  Everyone is really nice and ready to help.  That occassional raging noob will be gone in one or two games.

So... are you going to be the raging noob who quits after a few matches, the noob who enjoys seeing themself progress in a game with a large skill curve, or the ♥♥♥♥ing CS:GO Global Elite who owns us all?

See you in Ratz :-)

I was going through a rough time in my life. My parents were fighting constantly, I had no friends, and everyone I met hated me because I was fat. I needed something to prevent me from suicide. I could not find anything I really liked. I tried buying toys, but the store clerks always prevented me from buying anything because I was overweight. I tried making a vlog on YouTube about my troubles, but I was banned from youtube for supposedly impersonating Gabriel Iglesias. Google fined me all of my money until I only had $10 left.

The only things I had were things necessary for my survival. I was fed a potato every other day and also given water in a shot glass. Sometimes I forced myself to use the water as a way to bath instead of drinking it. I was locked in my room every day cuz my parents were busy fighting about which console to play on. Well, not entirely.

I had this netbook, one my parents got me for my birthday when I was 12. I used it for school, mostly, until now. I was also lucky enough to have a charger, and all the stuff you need to use the netbook. I decided, maybe give video games a try. No one would judge me there. I was unable to play the f2p games because A. They took too much storage and B. I would be banned whenever I joined a multiplayer game. I remembered the $10 I had left.

I knew I had to find something that gave me a reason to live. I looked through the steam store. Jesus almost nothing was $9.99! I was about to give up and just end my life when I found this game. Ratz Instagib. $9.99, without 10% tax. It took up all the space on my netbook. After waiting for it to download, I opened up the game. Upon opening it up there was a well made launcher with many options. Once I opened up the actual game, I heard a sweet jazz song, and saw some badass looking ratz and a cool map. Was this what I needed to continue living

It was. I am proud to say Ratz Instagib saved my life. The characters were deep, had personality, and I was able to connect with them. The story was unique, suspenseful, and I shed multiple tears. The graphics were revolutionary, and the soundtrack was the first good thing I had heard in awhile. It, in a way, provided everything I needed to live. The characters were my friends. The game was like a good parent. The game was easy to fap to. I could have just played the game for my entire life. It was amazing. It changed me. Here I am, sitting in my room, now infested with bullet ants and bees, starved half to death and with my throat about to dry up. But you know what? I do not care. Because I have Ratz Instagib. And I will always have Ratz Instagib. This game is my life now. I am finally happy. I am finally free. I know now the meaning of life. And only because  Lino Slahuschek games spent their time on this godly game.

This is because instead of normal games where the lagger sees everyone else jumping around the game compensates it and causes everyone to appear to be standing still while the lagger can take numerous hits without being killed.

The processing of hits is another issue I encountered while playing this game, that being sometimes you can shot someone and it will not process. That being the person will have the normal white outline/flash around them when hit, but then instead of exploding they turn around and shot you.

The final issue I have encountered within the game itself is the item reward system is completely broken. For example, I have had several times where I landed on a epic item, and instead get a common. When telling others about, I find out they landed on a common item and got an epic instead.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I'm not used to make reviews, but I have to make one for this game.

I'm a huge fan of Unreal Series, finished Painkiller 7 or 8 times already, and played most of the old-school First person shooters that came from 1998 to now.

I have to say first that I'm impressed, there has been a few studios lately who tried to make an old school shooter and that came with something unfinished, unpolished or just bad. And this game is on the road of being something really good for those who like the type.

First of all, most of the important things are here : Rail, Character and Crosshair Customisation, different types of matches (Freeze Tag, DM, TDM, CTF, Duel), a good number of maps and even different servers ! (EU-US-Japan).
That doesn't seem too much, but sometimes those kind of games are just empty, apart from the gameplay mechanics.

But unfortunatly, there are a few cons to that Unreal Mod paradise whick will turn you mad half of the time :

- Instagib Firerate. Well the concept of instagib, for those who don't know it, is to one-shot opponents. But when it fires like a freakin' machine-gun (2 shots per seconds approximatively), that can be really frustrating in some situations. It also makes missing forgivable, which is unforgivable in this unforgivable type of game, and forgive me if I'm repeating the word a few times, but I do like it, yeah. Let's add that 5 minutes is enough to make 30 kills. Although, as the game is faster than any other FPS you could have played before, this can be also considered as a part of the game. So, problem or not, it is your right to choose.
- Size of the maps. If you compare it to Quake for example, we can say that the maps are equally sized, but without walls. Most of them are sqarish and opened in the center, with only a few sofas to cover you. I'll explain later where is the problem with that part though. (I still have to give a point for the maps which are still pleasant to watch).
- 8 players Deathmatchs (because the other mods are not as popular as this one). And you can't change it yet. That shouldn't be a problem in theory, but when maps are as huge as your student bedroom, uh well... just imagine if you were a squirrel on a small road and that there were 6 trucks, 2 trains and a few planes rushing at you. That's the point. Make 1-2 kills and die. All the time. And if you are not used to this type of game, well you'll have time to enjoy the differents death animations at least...
- Respawn timer. 1.5 seconds it seems. And again, when you are 8 on a box, it makes respawn kill the easiest thing on the world to win. And it'll also eventually turn you sad. But that's a PvP game, so the community should be enough to make you depressive.

A few things to add, but you can't really consider it as cons. No voices for Double-Kill/Multi-kills etc..., a kind of Trance music on the background, which is good, but you don't feel the chills of KILLING MEN (Well I love Trance so I wasn't so unpleased, it's just that it does not really fit). And logically, no player limit when you host a server.

For those who thinks I'm just mad at losing, I actually won 2 times and get second for the two other times on my 4 first games. I really wanted to make a constructive review of the game.

I would still recommend it though, and I'm sure that it can be really fun if you are playing with friends on 4 players FFA or 2v2. And I even have to give credits to the developpers who, to my mind, made a fun and playable old-school first person shooter, unlike most of the other studios who recently failed on that task. It's just that on a new era of gaming with hundreds of new games every weeks (even dozens of free-to-play everydays), mistakes can't be allowed if you want to make your work worth your time.

7/10

For those who thinks I'm just mad at losing, I actually won 2 times and get second for the two other times on my 4 first games. I really wanted to make a constructive review of the game.

I would still recommend it though, and I'm sure that it can be really fun if you are playing with friends on 4 players FFA or 2v2. And I even have to give credits to the developpers who, to my mind, made a fun and playable old-school first person shooter, unlike most of the other studios who recently failed on that task. It's just that on a new era of gaming with hundreds of new games every weeks (even dozens of free-to-play everydays), mistakes can't be allowed if you want to make your work worth your time.

Even from the relatively small amount of this game I've played (compared to a lot of other players) I have to say it's an extremely fun and enjoyable experience. Mouse movements are responsive, with enemies getting killed in ways you know for sure they did. The boosting mechanic allows for great wall-hopping which can make for some spectacular air-shots on enemy players who prefer the ground. Customization options for players, the HUD and maps are nice as well.

Ratz Instagib's soundtrack is a bit too soft for this game in my opinion, but it can suit the game well in several moments. If you want a game soundtrack that fits this game more I'd try out Cube 2: Sauerbraten's songs as they're in the metal category. The game runs solid with over 190+ FPS on my setup and I've never experienced any lag issues on my own end.

Ratz Instagib is exactly what I want from a rail-gun arena shooter and more. Give it a try even if you're not too sure about the name and looks as I'm sure you'll have fun. There's even a survival mode against robots if you don't want to fight against enemy players.

Holy freaking hell I enjoyed this game. Probably more true to life of Quake 3 Arena then any other twitch shooter I've ever played. Other then Quake 3 Arena.

Do not be fooled by the screenshots, the graphics are very appealing, you can tweak the colours to suit your liking to help you focus and aim better. I do not see this as a way of cheating as everyone can tune to what helps them the most.

I'm not sure how much longevity I will get from this game, but the maps are already fantastic with few places to lock yourself up on.
The controls are perfect, I didnt need to change a thing from stock options and went straight into it raking up a decent score!
The fluidity is REALLY where this game shines, it just feels - so - right bunny hopping backwards, banking in on a target as you hit the ground and frag a player before leaping off into the air at 50mph.

If you want a good fun blast for cheap, with your freinds or solo online, I do recommend.

Do not expect lots of objectives and leveling up or perks, this game is simple and damned good at being just that.

This isn't a review, just how I felt about what I've just experienced.

Peace.

It's very fun and addictive, you can jump really long and fast which i like alot it's a very mobile game and when you first start to play you will play it more and more. The only complain i have is the Team Balance which comes every round where they pick some people on each team and switch them. There's freeze tag which is my favorite gamemode which includes 4 players on each team ( there's 4 players on each team no matter the gamemode, excluding Survival)
Then there's survival which is up to 8 players where you gotta play as a team to win against some NPC's and this is actually difficult from the start which i like alot too. It's not just one shot to kill it's actually 3 shots in it's core which is a little blue/green/red crystal in the middle of the npc. I strongly recommend this game if you like First Person Shooter games :)
